  • abdominal examination may reveal enlarged and palpable kidneys

Other points:

  • Gross haematuria following trauma is a classic presenting feature of ADPKD
  • Sometimes present with kidney failure (usually in the fourth to sixth decade of life)
  • May also present as asymptomatic on screening of family members
  • Intracranial aneurysm is an important extrarenal manifestation
  • Diagnosis: Ultrasound
  • Treatment: Nonspecific; management of hypertension

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, comes to the emergency department at 37 weeks gestation with the complaints of fatigue, headaches, and blurred vision for the past 3 days. The patient's pregnancy has been complicated by gestational hypertension that has not required antihypertensive therapy.Blood pressure is 170/110 mm Hg and pulse is 80/min. Physical examination shows edema of the hands and face. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+. Urine dipstick shows 3+ protein. A complete blood count and liver function panel are unremarkable. A biophysical profile shows a score of 8/8 and a fetus in vertex presentation. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?

choices.text: Reassure the patient, advise bed rest and analgesics
Add magnesium sulfate and start IV labetalol
Give oxytocin and deliver the baby
Give morphine and repeat biophysical profile.

questions.solution:
Eclampsia

  • Pre Eclamptic Toxemia with Generalized Tonic Clonic convulsions
  • Signs if severe HTN or Iminent Eclampsis
    • Headache
    • Nausea/Vomiting
    • Blurring of vision
    • Knee Jerks
    • Epigastric Pain
    • Proteinuria → >2gms/24 hrs urine (>3.5 gm/24hrs – Nephrotic range)
    • BP → >160/110 mm Hg

Eclampsia Management

  • DOC → MgSo4.7H­2O
    • IM + IV (Pritchard’s regimen- Method of choice)
    • IV only (Zuspan Regimen)
  • Pritchard’s Regimen
    • IV MgSo4 4gms IM MgSo4 10 gms (5gms in each buttock)
    • IV MgSo4 2 gms added if no relief
    • Follow up with
      • IM MgSO4 for 24 hrs after the last convulsion or the delivery whichever is later.
      • Monitor knee jerks → +

Respiratory Rate → >14/min

Urine Output → > 100 ml/4 hrs

  • Delivery is the most important step in the Mx of Elampsia
  • 90% or more are Normotensive within one week of delivery
  • Add IV Labetelol à DOC for Hypertensive emergencies in pregnancy

HYPERTENSION MANAGEMENT

  • Tab. LABETELOL
    • 1st Line drug
    • 100 - 200 mg TID
    • α +β blocker
  • Tab METHYL DOPA
    • Prodrug
    • Active corm → Methyl Norepinephrine
    • 250 - 500 mg QID
  • Tab. HYDRALAZINE
    • 25-50 mg BD or OD
    • Arteriolar dilator
  • TAB NIFEDEPINE
    • S/L Nifedepine is C/I (can cause sudden Hypotension when taken sub lingually)
    • 10 mg TID (upto 80 mg/ day can be given)
  • Tab PRAZOSIN
    • α Blocker
    • 2.5- 5 mg/day

CONTRAINDICATED DRUGS

  • Furosemide
  • β Blockers
  • Ace Inhibitors

questions.text:
Over the previous six months, a 28-year-old type 1 diabetic has experienced occasional diarrhoea and abdominal bloating. He also complains about being exhausted all of the time. The following are the results of his blood tests:

Haemoglobin 135 g/L (130-180 g/L)
Ferritin 30 ng/ml (20-300 ng/ml)
Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) 2.5 mU/L (0.5-5.7 mU/L)
Immunoglobulin A (IgA) tissue transglutaminase positive

What is the SINGLE most appropriate next step in action?

choices.text: Advice patients to go on a gluten-free diet

questions.solution:
• There is an association between type 1 diabetes and coeliac disease.
  • The gold standard to diagnose coeliac disease is a jejunal/duodenal biopsy.

Coeliac disease

  • Coeliac disease is caused by sensitivity to the protein gluten. Repeated exposure leads to villous atrophy which in turn causes malabsorption.

Signs and symptoms

  • Chronic or intermittent diarrhoea
  • Stinking stools/steatorrhoea
  • Persistent or unexplained gastrointestinal symptoms including bloating, nauseaand vomiting
  • Fatigue
  • Recurrent abdominal pain, cramping or distension
  • Sudden or unexpected weight loss
  • Unexplained iron, vitamin B12 or folate deficiency. Note that the one of themost common presentation of coeliac disease is iron deficiency anaemia. Also,folate deficiency is more common than vitamin B12 deficiency in coeliacdisease

Complications

  • Osteoporosis
  • T-cell lymphoma of small intestine (rare)

Investigation

Diagnosis is made by a combination of immunology and jejunal biopsy. Any test forcoeliac disease is accurate only if a gluten-containing diet is eaten during the diagnostic process. The person should not start a gluten-free diet until diagnosis is confirmed. Specific auto-antibodies

  • Tissue transglutaminase (TTG) antibodies (IgA)
  • Endomysial antibody (IgA)

Jejunal/duodenal biopsy

  • A biopsy is still needed to diagnose coeliac disease even if antibody test confirm thediagnosis of coeliac disease.
  • Villous atrophy
  • Crypt hyperplasia
  • Increase in intraepithelial lymphocytes

Management

  • Gluten-free diet

questions.text:
Mucosal haemorrhage and petechial rashes affect a 12-year-old girl. She's been feeling tired recently. on examination she looks pale. A blood count reveals the following:

Haemoglobin 74 g/L
White cell count 1.9 x 109/L
Neutrophils 0.1 x 109/L
Platelets 24 x 109/L

Blood film morphology was unremarkable. Reticulocytes are absent. A bone marrow aspirate shows a gross reduction in all haematopoietic tissue that is replaced by fat spaces. What is the SINGLE most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• She has signs and symptoms of anaemia. The blood picture shows pancytopenia which rules out pernicious anaemia as an underlying cause.
  • Normal morphology rules out the possibility of acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.
  • From the age alone we can exclude chronic myeloid leukaemia as it usuallypresents at age 40 to 50 years old (middle-age)
  • A bone marrow aspirate that shows a gross reduction in all haemopoietic tissue that is replaced by fat spaces is seen classically in aplastic anaemia. Absent reticulocytes support the diagnosis.

Aplasticanaemia

  • Aplastic anaemia is a rare, potentially life-threatening failure of haemopoiesis characterised by pancytopenia and hypoplastic marrow (the marrow stops making cells).

Causes Most

  • cases are autoimmune, triggered by drugs (viruses, eg parvovirus,hepatitis) or irradiation.

Presentation

  • Aplastic anaemia can present abruptly over, or insidiously over, weeks tomonths. Clinical manifestations are proportional to the peripheral-blood cytopenias and include:
  • Symptoms of anaemia (pallor, headache, palpitations, dyspnoea,fatigue, or ankle oedema) Note: Anaemic symptoms are usually less evere due to the chronic onset • Symptoms of thrombocytopenia (skin or mucosal haemorrhage,visual disturbance due to retinal haemorrhage, petechial rashes)
  • Infection (a less common presentation) particularly upper and lowerrespiratory tracts, skin, mouth, and peri-anal
  • There is no lymphadenopathy or hepatosplenomegaly (in theabsence of infection).

Diagnostic tests:

Marrow examination is needed for the diagnosis

Note: To define aplastic anaemia based on FBC and bone marrow findings, at least two of the following must be present:

  • Haemoglobin <10 g/dL
  • Platelet count < 50 x 109/L
  • Neutrophil count <1.5 x 109/L

It is also important to note that the blood film morphology is unremarkable which differentiates it from some other types of leukaemias.

questions.text:
Fatigue and palpitations affect a 41-year-old man. A red sore tongue, angular stomatitis, and koilonychia are discovered on physical examination. The results of his blood testing shows

Haemoglobin 85 g/
Mean cell volume 75 fL

What is the SINGLE most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Angular stomatitis, sore red tongue can ben seen in both B12 deficiency and iron deficiency although angular stomatitis is more of a sign of irondeficiency. Koilonychia is usually seen in iron deficiency.
  • But the key to the question is the mean cell volume. As this is decreased, it cannot be B12 deficiency or folate deficiency. Iron deficiency leads to microcytic anaemia so we would expect the MCV to be low. Iron-deficiency anaemia

Aetiology

  • Blood loss from the gastrointestinal (GI) tract is the most common cause of iron deficiency anaemia in adult men and post menopausal women
  • Blood loss due to menorrhagia is the most common cause of iron deficiency in premenopausal women
  • In tropical countries, infestation of the gut may cause iron deficiency anaemia , especially with hookworm and schistosomiasis
  • Common causes of blood loss include:
    • Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) use
    • Colonic carcinoma
    • Gastric carcinoma
    • Gastric or duodenal ulceration
    • Dietary inadequacy
    • Failure of iron absorption: Malabsorption conditions such as coeliacdisease
    • Excessive requirements for iron: Pregnancy

Laboratory tests

  • Low Haemoglobin
  • Low Mean cell volume (MCV)
  • Low Mean cell haemoglobin concentration (MCHC)
  • High Red cell distribution width (RDW)
  • Low serum ferritin
  • High Total iron-binding capacity

questions.text: In a patient with chronic stable angina, which medicine lowers the risk of cardiovascular death and increases life expectancy?
questions.solution:
• Due to oxygen conservation capability, beta blockers have been proved to reduce mortality in CSA.
  • Beta blockers are first-line therapyto reduce angina and improve exercise tolerance by limiting the heart rate response to exercise.
  • Calcium channel antagonists improve symptoms of angina via coronary and peripheral vasodilation. They areindicated for those who cannot tolerate or have insufficient control of ischemic symptoms on beta blockers alone.

questions.text: Which chromosome has a role in MEN1 pathogenesis?
questions.solution:
Chromosome aberrations in MEN

MEN 1 11q13
MEN 2 10 ( RET proto-oncogene)
MEN 3 10 ( RET Proto-oncogene)
MEN 4 12p13

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, at 29 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with gestational diabetes mellitus. Which of the following is NOT true about gestational diabetes mellitus?

choices.text: Cardiac anomalies like transposition of great arteries is the most common newborn complication in mothers with GDM.
Fetal lung maturity is delayed in GDM pregnancy.
Baby born to mother with GDM is at risk of hyperglycemia at birth.
Screening of GDM is done with Glucose Challenge Test at 24 weeks and blood sugar values >140 mg/dl is confirmed with Glucose Tolerance Test.

questions.solution:
Gestational DM

  • Presents around 24 week so screening done ≥ 24 wks
  • At 24 wks, Human Placental Lactogen made from placenta

  • No anomalies (organogenesis over) i.e. GDM does not cause Anomalies
  • Screening of GDM
    • Done after 24 wks
    • Glucose challenge test with 50 gms of sugar in a non-fasting woman → screening test (obsolete now)
    • Values after 1 hour should be <140 mg/dL
    • If values >140 mg/dL →? GDM

↓

    • Do confirmatory test → GTT with 100 gm glucose
    • If values > 200 mg/dL → Diagnostic of GDM
  • Glucose tolerance test (GTT) with 100 gms of sugar in a fasting woman → Diagnostic test (Obsolete now)
  • Fasting value → 105 mg/dL

↓

  • Give 100 gm of sugar/ Glucose to patient

1 hr value < 190

2 hr value < 165 Any 2 or more abnormal values

3 hr value < 145

↓

Diagnostic of GDM

  • 1 Step Test → Glucose tolerance test with 75 gms of sugar in a fasting woman (Screening & Diagnostic test now)
  • Fasting → <92 Any one abnormal valve
  • At 1 hr → < 180 Is Dx of GDM
  • At 2 hrs → < 153

Maternal Complications

  • Large baby
    • ↑ cesarean section
    • ↑ Instrumentation (Forceps and vaccum)

Birth canal injuries

Shoulder dystocia

PPH

  • Polyhydramnios → PROM → Chorioamnionitis
  • Peurperal sepsis
  • Pretermlabour
  • Associated with Pregnancy induced Hypertension (PIH) 25% cases
  • Abruption

  • Sudden intro uterine death at term

↓

Due to

  1. Poor glycaemic control
  2. Fetal lactic acidosis
  3. Maternal ketoacidosis
  4. Diabetic vasculopathy

Secondary to villous edema

↓

Compromises blood supply of Fetus leading to sudden death

Newborn Complications

  • Hypoglycemia ­

↑ Sugar in mother

↓

Reach fetus

↓

Fetus has healthy pancreas which makes increased insulin t metabolize sugars (also there is increased IGF which leads t Macrosomia)

↓

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has recently got an hCG injection for egg retrieval as part of her infertility treatment. She has developed lower abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting for the past 2 days. Physical examination shows a distended abdomen with normal bowel sounds and diffuse lower abdominal tenderness to deep palpation. Urine pregnancy test is positive.Transvaginal ultrasound shows bilateral ovarian enlargement with multiple cysts measuring up to 8 x 8 cm and intraabdominal fluid consistent with ascites.Doppler shows normal blood flow to both ovaries. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Normal course of in vitro fertilization

questions.solution:
Ovarian Hyper stimulation Syndrome. This rare event is typified by multiple ovarian follicular cysts accompanied by increased capillary permeability. It most often is a complication of ovulation-induction therapy for infertility, although it rarely may develop in an otherwise normal pregnancy. Its etiopathogenesis is thought to involve hCG stimulation of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) expression in granulosa-lutein cells (Soares, 2008). This causes increased vascular permeability that can lead to hypovolemia with ascites, pleural or pericardial effusion, acute kidney injury, and hypercoagulability. There is a clinical spectrum with symptoms that may include abdominal distention, rapid weight gain, dyspnea, and progressive hypo-volemia. Serious complications are renal dysfunction, adult respiratory distress syndrome, ovarian rupture with hemorrhage, and thromboembolism.

MANAGEMENT

Rx of DHSS

  • Avoid pregnancy in severe & critical forms
  • Remove fluids → Tap Ascites & effusion
  • Give oral fluids [Mild, moderate forms]

IV Fluids → NaCI, DNS [crystalloids]

→ Albumin, Dextran, starch [colloids]

  • Colloids will hold the fluid in the Intro-vascular space
  • MC →13-15% a pts on CLOMIPHENE CITRATE
  • Severe forms — GONADOTROPINS

Inj HMG [Human Menopausal Gonadotropins]

Inj FSH recombination

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with complaints of rash, abdominal pain, and nausea. The rash appeared first 2 days ago as red, round lesions on the back of thighs which eventually grew to involve both his legs and buttocks. The boy's appetite is decreased but he has no vomiting or diarrhea.His father gave a history of an upper respiratory infection last week. His vaccinations are complete for his age and his vitals are normal. On physical examination, his abdomen is soft, nondistended, and mildly tender to palpation in the periumbilical region.A palpable purpuric, non-blanching, non-tender erythematous rash was present on the feet, legs, and buttocks. Stool guaiac is positive.Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Henoch-Schönleinpurpura (HSP) or Ig A vasculitis is the most common vasculitis of childhood and is characterized by leukocytoclasticvasculitis and systemic immunoglobulin A deposition in the small vessels in the skin, joints, gastrointestinal tract, and kidney.

The hallmark of HSP is its rash: palpable purpura starting as pink macules or wheals and developing into petechiae, raised purpura, or larger ecchymoses. Occasionally, bullae and ulcerations develop. The skin lesions are usually symmetric and occur in gravity-dependent areas (lower extremities), extensor aspect of the upper extremities or on pressure points (buttocks).

Musculoskeletal involvement, including arthritis and arthralgias, is common, occurring in up to 75% of children with HSP. The arthritis tends to be self- limited and oligoarticular, with a predilection for large joints such as the knees and ankles, and does not lead to deformities.

Gastrointestinal (GI) manifestations occur in up to 80% of children with HSP and include abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, paralytic ileus, and melena. Intussusception, mesenteric ischemia, and intestinal perforation are rare but serious complications.

Renal involvement occurs in up to 30% of children with HSP, manifesting as microscopic hematuria, proteinuria, hypertension, frank nephritis, nephrotic syndrome, and acute or chronic renal failure.

HSP is diagnosed clinically, especially when the presentation is classic and involves lower-extremity purpura, as in this patient. Laboratory findings that support the diagnosis include a normal platelet count and coagulation studies and elevated inflammatory markers (eg, white blood cell count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate). Urinalysis may show casts, hematuria, pyuria, and proteinuria.

Treatment for mild and self-limited HSP is supportive, with an emphasis on ensuring adequate hydration, nutrition, and analgesia. Corticosteroids are most often used to treat significant GI involvement or other life-threatening manifestations.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding Down Syndrome?
i. Most common cause of trisomy 21 is due to translocation involving chromosome 21.
ii. Endocardial cushion defects in the heart and duodenal atresia are common in Down Syndrome.
iii. hCG and inhibin decrease in Down Syndrome iv)
iv. Increased nuchal fold thickness is the most sensitive radiological marker for Down Syndrome.
v. Integrated screening including first and second trimester screening is best for screening trisomy 21.
questions.solution:
Importance genetic syndromes:

  • Down syndrome
    • Mongoloid slant
    • Epicanthic folds
    • Depressed nasal bridge

  • Most common chromosomal abnormality seen in children
  • Basic defect
    • 3 copies of chr. 21 (trisomy 21)
  • Incidence – 1:800 – 1:1000 liver births

Genetic basis

  • 95% - maternal meiotic non disjunction (MC)
  • 3% - translocation
  • 1-2% - Mosaicism

Risk of having a child with down syndrome increase with increase in maternal age.

Mother age child Risk of down syndrome
20 year 1 in 1500
40 year 1 in 30

Clinical features

  • CVS
    • Endocardial cushion defects /AVSD (Atrio-ventricular septal defect) [most common CHD]
    • VSD, ASD, PDA
    • PAH
  • GIT
    • TEF
    • Duodenal atresia [most common cause of intestinal obstruction]
    • Annular pancreas
    • Hirschsprung disease
    • Imperforate anus
  • CNS
    • Lack of Moro’s reflex

Important feature (Mnemonic – ICA problem somewhere):

  • Incurved 5th finger (clinodactyly) / intellectual disability
  • Congenital heart disease / congenital hypothyroidism
  • Acute leukemia / Alzheimer’s disease (early onset) / Atlanto axial instability / absent Moro’s Reflex /Atresia of duodenum
  • Protruding tongue
  • Round face
  • Occiput flat / open, wide fontanelle
  • Brush field spots on iris / brachycephaly
  • Low (depressed) Nasal bridge, low tone (hypotonia)
  • Epicanthic fold / ears low set & dysplastic
  • Mongoloid slant (oblique palpebral fissure)
  • Sandle gap / simian palmar crease

Antenatal screening and diagnosis

Radiological markers (Antenatal USG)

  • Increased Nuchal fold thickness (>3 mm) – most sensitive
  • Absent nasal bones
  • Cardiac abnormalities
  • Duodenal atresia
  • Shortened femur

Biochemical markers:

  • First trimester screening
    • Biochemical markers (beta – HCG, pregnancy associated plasma protein A) [ dual markers ] combined test: maternal age + radiology + biochemical markers
  • Second trimester screening
    • Triple test (beta – HCG +AFP + unconjugated Estriol)
    • Quadruple test (Triple test + inhibin A)
    • Integrated test (best test for antenatal screening of down syndrome) [detection rate 95-97%]

Maternal age + T1 – (NT>3 mm + PAP –A) + T2 – (Quadruple test)

  • ‘HI’ – HCG and inhibin levels increase in Down syndrome
    • Confirmatory test for pre natal diagnosis of down syndrome: Fetal karyotype
  • Done by obtaining fetal genetic material by following methods.
Method Gestation Remarks
Chorionic villi sampling (CVS) 11-13 weeks Increase risk of abortions & fetal limb defects
Amniocentesis 14-16 weeks

Complications

  • Pregnancy loss
  • Amniotic fluid leakage
  • Vaginal bleeding
Cordocentesis (or) percutaneous umbilical cord blood sampling (PUBS)_ 17-20 weeks Fetal blood can be analysed directly by HPLC after ensuring that there is no maternal contamination
  • All these 3 procedures have increased risk of abortion

questions.text: The mother of a 6-year-old boy complains that his child passes urine while sleeping almost every night and has never been dry during the night-time. She reports that the boy can control his urine during the daytime. His growth is along 30th percentile for both his height and weight. Which of the following is the best next step in the initial management of his primary nocturnal enuresis?

choices.text: Recommend decreased intake of fluids and caffeine after evening along with motivational therapy

questions.solution:
Nocturnal enuresis:

Definition:- involuntary passage of urine at night beyond 5 yrs of age

Epidemiology

  • 60% are boys
  • Family history is positive in 50%
    • If 1 parent had nocturnal enuresis, each child has 44% risk of nocturnal enuresis
    • If both parents had nocturnal enuresis, each child has 77% risk of nocturnal enuresis

Types

  • Primary nocturnal enuresis – never attained urinary continence at night (more common)
  • Secondary nocturnal enuresis – previously normal at night & now develops nocturnal enuresis

Management

  • 1st line: diet & lifestyle changes
    • Restrict intake of caffeine, sugary substances / fluids after evening time
    • Give child early dinner & restrict intake of fluids after dinner + motivation therapy (start chart)
  • Maintain a diarly /calendar
    • For every dry day that the child has drawn a star
    • If the child has 7 consective stars, give gift to the child

2nd line: Bed alarm technique

  • There are moisture sensing alarms which are available
  • As soon as the child passes urine in bed, the alarm would detect the moisture in undergarment of the child & it will ring
  • Child wakes up, goes to toilet & micturates
  • Shown to produce excellent response

3rd line: drugs (used for refractory cases or short – term management)

  • Oral Desmopressin [nasal spray of desmopressin is no longer recommended d/t serious side effects]
  • Imipramine
  • Oxybutynin

Note: combination of drugs and bed & alarm technique – lowest relapse rates

questions.text: A 28 year old nulligravid woman presents with a complaint of lump in her right breast that she noticed a week ago. The size of the mass hasn’t changed since. On examination, roughly 2 cm round, mobile and tender mass is appreciated in the right outer quadrant. There is no nipple discharge, skin discoloration or axillary lymphadenopathy. What of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Provide reassurance and re-evaluate in 4 months

questions.solution:
In patients age <30, palpable breast masses (eg, fibroadenoma, fibrocystic change, cyst) are typically benign; however, malignancy must be excluded. Malignant breast masses are typically firm, immobile, and irregularly shaped, with associated skin changes or lymphadenopathy. In contrast, mobile breast masses are more consistent with benign disease. However, history and physical examination alone cannot reliably diagnose or exclude cancer, so further evaluation with breast imaging is required.

Role of UItrasound

  • First Investigation done in young females of age years with breast lump because these patients have dense and glandular breast for which sensitivity of mammography is low.
  • First investigation done in females & 35 years of age with breast lump-ultrasound

questions.text: Which of the following is a normal person's approximate extracellular fluid volume?
questions.solution: Sixty percent of the body mass is water. Of this water, one-third (20% of body mass) is extracellular and two-thirds (40% of body mass) is intracellular. The extracellular water is further divided into interstitial water (80% of extracellular fluid, or 15% of body mass) and plasma water (20% of extracellular fluid, or 5% of body mass). The percentage of water in the body is a function of body fat. The greater the percentage of body fat, the lower the percentage of body water. About three-fourths of the lean body mass (mass excluding fat) is water. The distribution of extracellular and intracellular water is a function of the extracellular osmolality. If the osmolality of the extracellular fluid is above normal, the proportion of water in the extracellular fluid, in comparison to that in the intracellular water, increases; hypotonicity of the extracellular water decreases the proportion of water in the extracellular fluid

questions.text: Excess secretion of which of the following will cause hyponatremia?
questions.solution: Vasopressin (AVP or ADH) increases water reabsorption from the cortical and medullary collecting ducts in the kidney. ADH is normally released in response to a rise in plasma Na+ concentration, and therefore the increased water reabsorption appropriately restores extracellular osmolarity toward normal. When excess ADH is excreted, the water reabsorption dilutes the extracellular fluid, producing a hypotonic hyponatremiaaccompanied by an increase in urinary sodium and urine osmolality. This condition is called the syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) and can be life-threatening. The etiology of SIADH includes idiopathic overproduction associated with CNS disorders (head trauma, stroke, encephalitis) and pulmonary disease (tuberculosis, pneumonia), ectopicADH production by malignant tumors, and drug-induced stimulation of the hypothalamic pituitaryaxis (vincristine, carbamezine, chlorpropamide). Patients with SIADH usually improve with fluid restriction

questions.text: A reduction in Paco2 is detected in a patient's arterial blood gas. Which of the following is a common cause of hyperventilation?
questions.solution: The alveolar and arterial PCO2 is determined as the rate of CO2 production divided by the rate of alveolar ventilation. Thus, at any given metabolic rate (rate of CO2 production = VCO2), hyperventilation is by definition a decrease in PaCO2. Pregnancy produces hyperventilation because progesterone stimulates the brainstem respiratory centers to increase alveolar ventilation. Sleep and morphine depress the respiratory centers and, therefore, produce hypoventilation. The compensatory response to metabolic alkalosis is a small decrease in alveolar ventilation. During exercise, alveolar ventilation increases in proportion to carbon dioxide production such that the arterial PCO2 remains normal. Thus the increased rate of alveolar ventilation in exercise is not hyperventilation, but it has been given a special term, called exercise hyperpnea.

questions.text: With acute chest pain, a 56-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department. Angiography reveals a significant blockage of the coronary arteries. To reestablish perfusion, a thrombolytic agent is used. Which of the following is activated by the thrombolytic agent?
questions.solution: Plasminogen is the inactive precursor of plasmin, the proteolytic enzyme involved in clot dissolution. An infusion of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) soon after a heart attack (and possibly a thrombolytic stroke) can lessen the chances of permanent damage. Thrombin, the enzyme ultimately responsible for the formation of fibrin monomers, is generated from prothrombin by activated factor X. Activation of factor X occurs via both extrinsic and intrinsic pathways. Kininogens are enzymes responsible for the production of peptides (kinins) associated with inflammation. Heparin is an anticlotting agent found on endothelial cell surfaces.

questions.text: Which of the following is dependent on the precentral gyrus and corticospinal tract?
questions.solution: The precentral gyrus is the motor area of the cortex that contains the cell bodies of the neurons that form the corticospinal tract (also referred to as the pyramidal tract). The corticospinal tract contains axons that cross to the contralateral side of the brain within the pyramids and end within the motor areas of the spinal cord. These structures are essential for the generation of fine voluntary movements. Kinesthesia, the sense of movement and position of the limbs, is handled primarily by the Ia and Ib afferents that innervate the muscle spindles and Golgi tendon organs, respectively, and by the parietal lobe.

questions.text: When he travels long distances for meetings, a 41-year-old guy complains to his doctor about jet lag. Melatonin is being provided to help him re-establish his circadian rhythm. Which of the following regulates the circadian rhythm?
questions.solution:
A variety of physiological functions, such as alertness (the sleep-wake cycle), body temperature, and secretion of hormones, exhibits cyclic activity that varies over a 24-h period of time. These variations in activity are called circadian rhythms and are controlled by the suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus.

The paraventricular nucleus secretes oxytocin and vasopressin, the ventromedial and lateral nuclei control food intake, and the arcuate nucleus secretes gonadotropin-releasing hormone.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presented to the hospital with a hypokinetic movement disorder characterized by bradykinesia (paucity and slowness of movement). Which of the following occurs during a normal voluntary movement?

choices.text: Large muscle fibers are recruited before small muscle fibers
Fast muscle fibers are recruited before slow muscle fibers
Weak muscle fibers are recruited before strong muscle fibers
Poorly perfused muscle fibers are recruited before richly perfused muscle fibers

questions.solution: In general, small, weak, slow, fatigue-resistant muscle fibers are innervated by small spinal motoneurons, whereas, large spinal motoneurons innervate large, fast, strong, easily fatigable muscle fibers. During most normal reflex or voluntary movements, small spinal motoneurons are recruited before large motoneurons. The slow fatigue-resistant muscle fibers have a dense capillary network for perfusion and use mitochondrial oxidative metabolism to produce adenosine triphosphate (ATP).

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy has delayed dentation, is small in stature, has trouble and pain while walking, and his legs are bending. Which of the following is a problem in bone with vitamin D deficiency?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin D deficiency causes defective calcification of the bone matrix as a result of inadequate delivery of Ca2+ and PO43– to the sites of mineralization. The disease in children is called rickets, and is characterized by growth retardation, weakness and bowing of the weight-bearing bones, dental defects, and hypocalcemia, which increases parathyroid hormone and urinary phosphate losses.
  • Several different types of inheritance lead to the vitamin D deficiency disorders, including X-linked dominant and autosomal dominant hypophosphatemic rickets, vitamin D-dependent rickets Type I, an autosomal recessive disorder caused by inactivating mutations in the gene encoding 1a-hydroxylase enzyme, and vitamin D-dependent rickets Type II, in which there is end-organ resistance to 1,25(OH)2D3, which is also usually inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder.

questions.text: Meningitis strikes an 18-year-old college student residing in a dorm, causing a centrally controlled rise in his respiratory rate. Which of the following brain regions generates the basic respiratory rhythm?
questions.solution: The main components of the respiratory control pattern generator for the automatic control of breathing are located in the medulla. The basic respiratory rhythm is initiated by a small group of synaptically coupled pacemaker cells in the pre-Bötzinger complex on either side of the medulla between the nucleus ambiguus and the lateral reticular nucleus. This basic rhythm can be modified by many factors, including higher centers in the cerebral cortex and hypothalamus and input from the reticular activating system and pontine respiratory centers, including the pneumotaxic center in the nucleus parabrachialis.

questions.text: A patient presents with a chief complaint of fatigue. He had an increase in heart rate and respiratory rate. The history also revealed symptoms of chills and spiking fever. The right lower lobe was dull to percussion. Vocal fremitus was increased over the right lower lobe and bronchovesicular breathing was present in the region, as well. Ventilation-perfusion (V ?/Q ?) abnormalities occurring in a patient with lobar pneumonia will generally cause a decrease in which of the following?
questions.solution: V ?/Q ? mismatches will cause arterial oxygen levels (PaO2) to decrease. Decreased PaO2 will stimulate the peripheral chemoreceptors, which, in turn, will increase alveolar ventilation and decrease PaCO2. The decreased PaCO2 will cause a respiratory alkalosis (increasing pH). Hypoxemia may also cause lactate levels to rise, increasing the anion gap (and blunting the rise in pH).

questions.text: A 22-year-old lady is admitted to the hospital after experiencing respiratory distress, fever, and exhaustion. ST segment and T wave anomalies indicate myocarditis, which is thought to be caused by a viral infection. Significant peripheral edoema occurs during the next few days. Which of the following is the most likely cause of edoema?
questions.solution:
Net filtration from systemic capillaries is dependent on the Starling forces and capillary permeability.

The equation is

Net filtration = Kf [(Pcapillary – Ptissue) – (πcapillary – πtissue)],where Kf is the filtration coefficient of the membrane, and is directly proportional to capillary permeability, Pcapillary and Ptissue are the hydrostatic pressures in the capillary and tissue (interstitial space), respectively, and πcapillary and πtissue are the osmotic (colloid oncotic) pressures in the capillary and interstitial space, respectively.

Increasing central venous pressure increases the capillary hydrostatic pressure (Pcapillary), which increases the filtration of fluid from the systemic capillaries, leading to edema. All of the other choices will cause a decrease in filtration.

questions.text: A 42-year-old lady is transported to the emergency room with lightheadedness and recurrent syncope, and she is administered atropine. An increase in which of the following alleviates her symptoms?
questions.solution: Although the cause of her syncope is not given in the history, it is presumably produced by an abnormally slow heart rate due to increased release of acetylcholine by the vagus nerve or by acetylcholine agonists such as muscarine, which is found in certain mushrooms. Atropine blocks the acetylcholine receptors on the SA and AV node, leading to an increased heart rate.

questions.text: A 52-year-old guy was taken to the emergency room after vomiting for the second time in two hours. His vomit is dark brown in colour and gritty in texture. After meals, the patient gets dyspepsia, for which he takes over-the-counter antacids. Mild epigastric soreness is discovered during a physical examination. Endoscopy reveals a severe, bleeding ulcer on the duodenal bulb's posterior wall. Which of the following arteries has this ulcer most likely penetrated?
questions.solution:
Duodenal ulcers are more common than gastric ulcers and tend to occur anteriorly. Ulcers located in the anterior wall of the duodenal bulb are more prone to perforation, those on the posterior wall are more likely to cause hemorrhage.

These complications are explained by the relationship of the duodenal bulb to adjacent organs. The bulb begins at the pylorus, ends at the neck of the gallbladder and rests posterior to the gall bladder and liver. The gastroduodenal artery, common bile duct and portal vein lie posterior to the duodenal bulb, the head of the pancreas is located inferiorly. When an ulcer penetrates the posterior duodenal wall, it is likely to erode gastroduodenal artery (Option d).

The gastroduodenal artery arises from the common hepatic artery and perfuses both the pylorus and the proximal part of the duodenum. Damage to the gastroduodenal artery can cause significant upper gastrointestinal bleeding.

Option a - The common hepatic artery arises from the celiac trunk and bifurcates into the proper hepatic and gastroduodenal arteries. It passes superior to the duodenal bulb and is not eroded by duodenal ulcers.

Option b and c – The right gastroepiploic and left gastric arteries supply blood to the stomach. They do not lie in close proximity to the duodenal bulb

questions.text: Which of the following veins is most typically swollen when the inferior mesenteric vein is compressed immediately before it enters the splenic vein?

In compression of the inferior mesenteric vein its tributaries like left colic vein gets enlarged - Venous drainage of Hind-Gut territory.

Left gastroepiploic (gastro-omental) vein (option 2) drains into splenic vein.

Inferior pancreaticoduodenal vein (option 3) drains into supperior mesenteric vein- Venous drainage of Hind-Gut territory.

The blood within the portal vein carries high levels of nutrients from the GI tract and products of red blood cell destruction from the spleen.

questions.text: Which of the following types of ribs is not precisely matched.

questions.text: A 60-year-old Caucasian man with serious mental deficit is taken to his physician from an institution. When the doctor looks up his family history, he discovers that he has an older sister who is also a patient at the same facility. Their parents are no longer alive, but they were said to have normal IQ and no chronic illnesses. The man sits in an unusual position, as if sewing, causing the doctor to order a ferric chloride test on his urine. With aromatic (ring) substances, such as some amino acids, this test turns green, confirming the physician's diagnosis. In the man's urine, which of the following amino acids was most likely detected?
questions.solution: Phenylalanine, with its benzene ring, is an essential amino acid that is converted to tyrosine by phenylhydroxylase, the enzyme (or its cofactor biopterin) that is deficient in phenylketonuria (PKU—MIM*261600). The other amino acid choices (incorrect answers a-c and e) do not have aromatic (benzene ring) side chains—serine has a hydroxyl group, glutamine an amino group, and methionine a sulfhydryl group. Deficiency of phenylalaninehydroxylase in PKU causes elevated substrate (phenylalanine) and deficient product (tyrosine), leading to developmental delays and ultimately severe mental retardation if the disease is not recognized. Now children with PKU are detected by newborn screening and placed on low-phenylalanine diets that allow normal brain development. Adults can moderate the greatly restricted and not very tasty diet but may elect to go back on for clear thinking before exams or, in the case of affected females, to prevent birth defects caused by high maternal phenylalanine in pregnancy.

questions.text: Acid hydrolysis of the proenzyme form activates which of the following proteolytic enzymes?
questions.solution: Pepsin is secreted in a proenzyme form in the stomach. Unlike the majority of proenzymes, it is not activated by protease hydrolysis. Instead, spontaneous acid hydrolysis at pH 2 or lower converts pepsinogen to pepsin. Hydrochloric acid secreted by the stomach lining creates the acid environment. All the enzymes secreted by the pancreas are activated at the same time upon entrance into the duodenum. This is accomplished by trypsin hydrolysis of the inactive proenzymes trypsinogen, chymotrypsinogen, procarboxypeptidase, and proelastase. Primer amounts of trypsin are derived from trypsinogen by the action of enteropeptidase secreted by the cells of the duodenum.

questions.text: Which of the following could cause an increase in hemoglobin's affinity for O 2?

choices.text: Initial binding of O 2 to one of the four sites available in each deoxyhemoglobin molecule

questions.solution:
The addition of each O 2 molecule to deoxyhemoglobin requires the breakage of salt links, such as those formed by 2,3-BPG. Each subsequent O 2 molecule requires the breakage of fewer salt links. Thus, initial O 2 binding actually results in an increased affinity for subsequent O 2 binding, which in turn produces “cooperativity” and a sigmoidal shape to the oxygen-binding curve. The lower pH of acidosis (incorrect answer b), higher carbon dioxide levels (incorrect answer c), lower BPG levels (incorrect answer b), and more ferric ion (incorrect answer c)—all cause less affinity for oxygen; all but the latter option occur in peripheral tissues to facilitate oxygen delivery.

BPG binds specifically to deoxyhemoglobin; that is, BPG cross-links positively charged residues on the β chain, thereby decreasing oxygen affinity and stabilizing the deoxygenated form of hemoglobin. CO 2 reacts reversibly with the amino acid terminals of hemoglobin to create carbaminohemoglobin, which is negatively charged and forms salt bridges, stabilizing deoxyhemoglobin. Hence, CO 2 binding lowers the affinity of hemoglobin for O2

questions.text: A sigmoidal plot of substrate concentration ([S]) vs initial reaction velocity (Vi) in the study of enzymes may suggest which of the following?

choices.text: Suicidal inhibition where the enzyme catalyzes the formation of inhibitor

questions.solution: Allosteric enzymes often have several binding sites for substrate and/or cofactors, such that one active site positively affects another active site in the same molecule. This leads to cooperatively and sigmoidal enzyme kinetics in a plot of substrate [S] versus initial reaction velocity [Vi ]. The terms competitive inhibition and noncompetitive inhibition apply to Michaelis– Menten kinetics and not to allosteric enzymes . Suicidal inhibition where a substrate is converted to inhibitor would be similar to competitive inhibition with Michaelis–Menten kinetics

questions.text: An 18-year-old Korean college student attends a fraternity party and is embarrassed because after his first glass of alcohol, he becomes flushed and ill to his stomach. He discovers that this reaction is caused by genetic variation that impairs the metabolism of an alcohol metabolite in some Asians and Native Americans. Which of the following is the metabolite that degrades in different ways?
questions.solution:
The principal pathway for hepatic metabolism of ethanol is thought to be oxidation to acetaldehyde in the cytoplasm by alcohol dehydrogenase. Acetaldehyde is then oxidized, chiefly by acetaldehyde dehydrogenase within the mitochondrion, to yield acetate. Acetone, methanol and hydrogen peroxide do not appear in this biodegradation pathway, eliminating answers a-b, d.

The genetic variations of acetaldehyde dehydrogenase have few phenotypic effects aside from sensitivity to alcoholic beverages and are Carbohydrate Metabolism Answers 133 extremely common in the affected populations. These characteristics qualify acetaldehyde dehydrogenase variation as an example of enzyme polymorphism. Alcohol sensitivity is less of a factor in alcohol overdose or poisoning, where large intake overwhelms the liver’s capacity to metabolize about ounce per hour. Symptoms of coma and impending respiratory arrest mandate emergency room treatment to support respiration, avoid aspiration, reverse hypoglycemia (with IV dextrose), and restore depleted thiamine.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes why people with hyperlipidemia and/or gout should avoid sucrose and high-fructose syrups?

choices.text: Fructose can bypass phosphofructokinase using a fructokinase in liver
Fructose can be phosphorylated by hexokinase in liver cells
Fructose is converted to UDP-fructose in liver
Fructose is ultimately converted to galactose in liver

questions.solution: Fructose is taken in by humans as sucrose, sucrose-containing syrups, and the free sugar. In liver, fructose is phosphorylated to fructose 1-phosphate by liver fructokinase, allowing it to bypass the ATP-regulated phosphofructokinase, yield glyceraldehyde and dihydroxyacetone phosphate by aldolase cleavage, and increase triglyceride/lipid biosynthesis . Fructose phosphorylation can also deplete liver cell ATP, lessening its inhibition of adenine nucleotide degradation and increasing uric acid that is the problem in gout. In adipocytes, fructose can be alternatively phosphorylated by hexokinase to fructose 6-phosphate. However, this reaction is competitively inhibited by appreciable amounts of glucose, as it is in other tissues.

questions.text: Ammonia levels will be raised in some organic acidemias or fatty acid oxidation diseases. This refers to the location of urea cycle processes, which occur in which of the following?

choices.text: In the mitochondrial matrix and the cytosol

questions.solution: The steps of the urea cycle are divided between the mitochondrial matrix and cytosol of liver cells in mammals. The formation of ammonia, its reaction with carbon dioxide to produce carbamoyl phosphate, and the conversion to citrulline occur in the matrix of mitochondria. Citrulline diffuses out of the mitochondria, and the next three steps of the cycle, which result in the formation of urea, all take place in the cytosol. Fatty acid oxidation and some reactions of organic acid degradation also occur in the mitochondria.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures produces the greatest amount of ATP?
questions.solution:
The pentose phosphate pathway does not generate any ATP but instead forms NADPH and ribose phosphate (incorrect answer d).

Glycolysis produces a net two ATP molecules per glucose (incorrect answer c) .

The citric acid cycle produces a net 12 ATP per turn of the cycle (incorrect answer a).

Fatty acid oxidation of palmitate results in a total of 129 ATP. Electron transport in the respiratory chain results in 5 ATP for each of the first 7 acetyl-CoA produced by the oxidation of palmitate for a total of 35 ATP.

questions.text: Several weight-loss regimens are centred on lowering carbohydrate intake to prevent insulin release from being stimulated; insulin controls hunger and inhibits lipolysis. The most significant increase in plasma concentration of which of the following is the proposed technique of measuring the success of minimal carbohydrate intake during fasting?
questions.solution:
Urine ketone measurements by dipstick were recommended for monitoring of success in limiting carbohydrate intake (incorrect answers a-c).

Under fed conditions, glucose is the preferred fuel for most tissues. However, under starvation conditions, glucose must be reserved for use by the central nervous system. There is a small initial decrease in plasma glucose upon starvation but the concentration levels off after a time because of conversion of glycogen in the liver. Under starvation conditions, ketone bodies are made in the liver and provide a major metabolic fuel source for skeletal and heart muscle and can serve to meet some of the brain’s energy needs. Another effect of starvation and carbohydrate limitation is accelerated lipogenesis and elevated serum cholesterol/triglycerides, which was exaggerated by substituting fat (meat, eggs) in one famous low-carbohydrate diet. These effects may have contributed to the sudden collapse and death of the diet’s founder; low-fat, heart-friendly low carbohydrate diets have since been promoted

questions.text: In patients who do not have a mutated repair pathway, which of the following is the correct sequence of events in gene repair mechanisms?

choices.text: Nicking, excision, replacement, sealing, and recognition
Nicking, recognition, excision, sealing, and replacement
Nicking, sealing, recognition, excision, and replacement
Recognition, nicking, excision, replacement, and sealing

questions.solution:
In all of the forms of DNA repair in normal cells, a common sequence of events occurs:

  1. The single or multiple base abnormality is surveyed and detected by a specific protein or proteins.
  2. The DNA is nicked on one side of the damaged DNA.
  3. A specific enzyme excises the damaged portion (steps 2 and 3 can be combined if an exonuclease cuts on both sides of the damaged DNA).
  4. The damaged portion of the strand is replaced by resynthesis catalyzed by DNA polymerase I.
  5. A ligase seals the final gap.
  6. With some variability, these general principles apply in nucleotide excision repair (segments of about 30 nucleotides), base excision repair of single bases, and mismatch repair of copying errors (1-5 bases).

questions.text: Which of the following statement is NOT correct about liver transplantation?

choices.text: In orthotopic liver transplantation, the graft is placed at the normal anatomic position after recipient hepatectomy.
Age > 70 years is an absolute contraindication for liver transplantation.
Vanishing bile duct syndrome can occur as part of chronic liver graft rejection.
Most common indication for re-transplantation in liver transplant is primary non-function of graft.

questions.solution:
Contraindications for Liver transplantation

Absolute Relative
  • Advanced cardiopulmonarydisease
  • Active untreatedsepsis
  • Metastatic malignancy toliver
  • Active alcoholabuse
  • Severe intractabledepression
  • Extensive venousthrombosis
  • Age (>70 Years) – varies among transplant centers·
  • Obesity (BMI>440kg/m2)·
  • Cholangiocarcinoma·
  • Chronic or refractory activeinfection
  • Ongoing tobacco use or illegal druguse

Types of Liver Transplantation

  • OrthotopicLT – graft placed at normal anatomical position after recipient hepatectomy ·
  • Heterotopic LT - graft is placed at an alternative site rather than at normal anatomical position ·
  • Auxiliary LT - native liver remains IN-SITU and whole or partial transplant is added ·
  • APOLT (Auxiliary Partial Orthotopic LT) - Left lobe of recipient is excised& donor liver occupies the vacated space
  • Auxiliary Heterotopic LT - Either whole liver or lobe of liver is placed in subhepatic space ·
  • Piggyback LT - Orthotopic LT that preserves IVC ·
  • Split LT - Cadaveric liver is divided and given to 2 recipients
    • Left lobe given to child; Right lobe given to adult
  • Reduced LT - graft is reduced to a functional unit of appropriate size for recipient

Explanation-

  • Hepatic artery thrombosis
    • Occurs spontaneously or part of acute graft rejection
    • Patient develops fever & bile leak
    • Increased Serum Transaminase
    • Mgt: Immediate re – transplantation
  • Portal Vein thrombosis
    • Occurs insidiously
    • Does not required Re-transplantation
  • Chronic liver graft rejection
    • Occurs due to Vanishing bile duct syndrome
    • Liver is relatively resistant to hyper acute rejection
    • Chronic rejection is uncommon in LT
  • Bile leak
  • Biliary strictures
  • M/C cause of death after LT, Heart transplantation, Small bowel transplantation – Sepsis and Sepsis related MOF

Indications for Re-transplantation

  • MC indication for Re-transplantation – Primary Non-function Hepatic artery thrombosis>Acute and Chronic rejection>Recurrent disease

questions.text: The aetiology of a disease is its cause or origin. Which among the following is the most difficult criterion to establish Causal association in aetiology of a disease?
questions.solution:
Specificity of associationmeans that the disease is caused by a particular risk factor.

  • It is difficult criterion to establish, as it is difficult to rule out the same outcomes by other exposures.

Other Hill's criteria of causal association/ Surgeon general's criteria include:

  • Temporality
  • Consistency
  • Strength [RR/ Odd's ratio]
  • Biological plausibility
  • Coherence
  • Dose response relationship

questions.text: In a study it was found that eating vegetables rich in beta-carotene could reduce cancer. But there can be other factors like high fiber diet, which could also be responsible for this. This is due to
questions.solution:
• High fiber diet is associated with vegetables rich in beta-carotene.
  • Also, high fiber diet is associated with decreased incidences of certain cancers especially colonic cancers.
  • Now, since the high-fiber diet is present with both the cause and the effect independently and is distributed unevenly in the case and the control group, it can be called aconfounding factor.
  • Also, it can be due to multifactorial causation, if both carotene and high fiber diet are associated with reduced cancer incidence.
  • Since we have to select only one option, and from other studies we do know that vitamin doesn’t decrease the risk of cancer, the best option will be confounding factor.

questions.text: Benzodiazepines are known to directly affect actions of which of the following neurotransmitter?
questions.solution: The pharmacological action of benzodiazepines (BDZ) requires presence of GABA which is an inhibitory neurotransmitter. Receptors for benzodiazepines are present at presynaptic sites. GABA receptors are present all over the cortex but most dense in limbic system and spinal cord. BDZ enhance the effect of GABA on its receptors which result in anticonvulsant, muscle relaxant, anxiolytic and sedative effects.

questions.text: A delusion is an example of
questions.solution:
A delusion is a false fixed belief which is out of keeping with the person’s educational, cultural, and social background. Delusional believes are not arrived at through normal logical thought processes and subjectively are indistinguishable from true believes.

Formal thought disorder is a series of disturbances in the way that thoughts are linked together.

Auditory hallucinations are noises, voices or music experienced without any external stimuli.

Passivity experiences are subjective disturbances in the control of thinking which becomes so disorganized that thought processes are ascribed to outside influences.

questions.text: Demography is the scientific study of human population. Which of the following is not included in Demographic processes?
questions.solution:
Demography is the scientific study of human population. It focuses its attention on three readily observable human phenomena:

  1. Changes in population size (growth or decline)
  2. Composition of the population and
  3. Distribution of population in space.

It deals with5 "demographic processes" like

  • fertility
  • mortality
  • marriage
  • migration &
  • social mobility

These five processes are continuously at work within a population determining size, composition and distribution.

questions.text: All of the following drugs are used in alcohol de-addiction except?
questions.solution:
ALCOHOL DE-ADDICATION

  • Benzodiazepines(chlordiazepoxide and diazepam) are given toprevent withdrawal.
  • These arelong acting CNS depressantsand can be withdrawn gradually.
  • Naltrexoneis an opioid antagonist that can be used toreduce alcohol craving.
  • Acamprosateis anNMDA antagonistthat can be used formaintenance therapy of alcohol abstinence.
  • Disulfiramcan be used in psychologically dependent persons who are motivated to quit alcohol.
  • It iscontraindicated in physically dependentindividuals. Disulfiram produces severe distressing symptoms.
  • Topiramate and ondansetroncan alsodecrease alcohol craving.

questions.text: Amongst the following extrapyramidal side effect is commonest with which drug?
questions.solution:
Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic drug and has negligible risk of extrapyramidal symptoms.

  • Atypical antipsychotic drugs act byantagonistic actions at 5-HT2andalphareceptorsand may ormay not possess D2 blocking activity.
  • These drugs areless likely to cause extrapyramidal symptoms.
  • However, most of these agents(except ziprasidone and aripiprazole)can result inweight gain, hyperlipidaemia and new-onset diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs inhibits plasminogen activation?
questions.solution:
• Epsilon amino caproic acid (EACA) and tranexamic acid are specific antidotes for overdose of fibrinolytic agents.
  • These are called as anti-fibrinolytic drugs

questions.text: Which of the following β2 agonists is given by inhalation, and is suitable for both terminating acute asthma attacks as well as for twice daily prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
• Terbutalineis a fast-acting bronchodilator useful for terminating the acute attack of bronchial asthma.Due toshort duration of action, it is not suitable for chronic prophylaxis.
  • Bambuterol is a prodrug ofTerbutaline
  • Bambuterol, salmeterol and formoterol are long acting β2 agonists useful for chronic prophylaxis.
  • Bambuterolandsalmeterolaredelayed acting,therefore are not suitable for acute attacks.
  • Formoterolisfast actingalso, therefore can be used for the treatment of acute attack of asthma.

questions.text: A 48year old female who was a known case of severe mitral stenosis on treatment, posted for mitral valve replacement under general anesthesia while induction, Inj. Thiopentone sodium was given accidentally through arterial line. The management of this patient does not include-

choices.text: Stellate ganglion block can cause sympathectomy and vasodilation
Papaverine is used for dilatation of artery which is in spasm
Heparin is given to prevent thrombosis
Stop the injection and remove the cannula

questions.solution:
Intra-arterial injection may cause immediate intense vasoconstriction and excruciating pain radiates along the distribution of the artery. Severe extremity ischaemia, gangrene and permanent nerve damage can occur. The degree of injury is related to the concentration of the drug.

Treatment:

  • Theneedle should not be removedand saline is administered via the same needle so as to dilute the drug
  • Prevention of arterial spasm by injecting vasodilators (lidocaine, papaverine)
  • Administering heparinto prevent thrombosis
  • Brachial plexus block

questions.text: A 30 year old female who was a case of fibroadenoma of left breast posted for lumpectomy under general anesthesia.Anesthesia was induced with Inj.Propofol and endotracheal intubation was facilitated with Inj.Vecuronium.At the end of surgery, the neuromuscular blockade was reversed with Inj.Neostigmine and extubated.The drug which is used to antagonize the visceral side effects of neostigmine during reversal of vecuronium blockade in this patient would be-
questions.solution:
• Anticholinergic drugs (e.g. atropine, glycopyrrolate) are routinely administered with anticholinesterases in order toattenuate the undesirable muscarinic effects(Bronchoconstriction, increased airway resistance, increased salivation and increased bowel motility)during reversal of neuromuscular blockade.
  • Atropine (7-10 mcg/kg) matches the onset of action and pharmacodynamic profile of rapid acting edrophonium (0.5-1 mg/kg)or glycopyrrolate (7-15 mcg/kg) matches slower acting neostigmine(40-70 mcg/kg) and pyridostigmine to prevent muscarinic side effects.
  • Glycopyrrolate is used as a pre-anesthetic agent for reducing the secretions and it can be used in patients with pre-existing cardiac disease (Anticholinesterases and anticholinergic should be administered slowly)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a low flow variable performance system?
questions.solution:
• Venturi mask is high flow fixed performance system. All other options are low flow variable performance system.
  • Low flow variable systems have advantage over high flow fixed performance that they are cheap and have better patient tolerance.
  • Other examples of high flow fixed performance are anaesthetic bag, air-entraining nebulizers.

questions.text: Fastest to slowest route of absorption of local anaesthetic is?

choices.text: Tracheal > Intercostal block > Lumbar epidural > Subcutaneous.

questions.solution:
• The rate of systemic absorption local anaesthetic is greatest with intercostal nerve blocks followed by caudal, lumbar epidural, brachial plexus block femoral and sciatic nerve blocks.
  • Sequence of systemic absorption of local anaesthetics (from fastest to lowest with the time to peak blood levels)
  • Intravenous > Tracheal > Intercostal block (8-9 min) > Para cervical block(10 min) >Intramuscular(12 min) > Caudal > Lumbar epidural(intermediate at 15 min) >Axillary block(20 min) > Brachial Plexus block(25 min) >Subarachnoid block(20-30 min) > Sciatic-femoral block (30 min)> Subcutaneous sites.

questions.text: The demographic goal is to achieve Net Reproduction Rate (NRR) = 1. This can be achieved only if the Couple Protection Rate (CPR) exceeds by?
questions.solution:
Couple Protection Rate (CPR)

  • It is defined as the percent of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or other approved methods of family planning, viz. sterilization, IUD, condom or oral pills.
  • It is an indicator of prevalence of contraceptive practice in the community.
  • Demographers are of the view that the demographic goal of NRR= 1 can be achieved only if the CPRexceeds 60 percent.
  • To achieve NNR=1, ideal contraception isSterilization. [vasectomy]

questions.text: After family planning education in a rural PHC, A 29 year old female presented to the hospital for sterilization operation. All of the following are the Guidelines for Sterilization except?

choices.text: The age of the husband should not ordinarily be less than 25 years nor should it be over 50 years
The age of the wife should not be less than 20 years or more than 45 years.
The motivated couple must have 3 living children at the time of operation.
If the couple has 3 or more living children, the lower limit of age of the husband or wife may be relaxed at the discretion of the operating surgeon

questions.solution:
Guidelines for sterilization

  1. Age of the husband should not be < 25 years nor > 50 years.
  2. Age of the wife should not be < 20 years or > 45 years.
  3. Motivated couple must have ≥ 1 living children at the time of Sx.
  4. If the couple has ≥3 living children, the lower limit of age of the husband/wife may be relaxed at the discretion of the operating surgeon.
  5. If the acceptor declares having obtained the consent of his/her spouse to undergo sterilization without outside pressure, inducement or coercion, and that he/she knows that for all practical purposes, the operation is irreversible, and also that the spouse has not been sterilized earlier.

questions.text: A 5year old baby was brought to the hospital to get vaccinated by his mother. According to the latest guidelines of vaccination, which of the following is applicable for this age?
questions.solution:
According to Latest National immunization Schedule - NIS 2020-21:

  • Total 3 doses of DPT vaccine each at 6,10 & 14 weeks; & 2 booster doses each at [16-24 months] & 5yrs of age are given respectively.
  • Vitamin A should be started at 9months of age [1 lakh IU] & given for every 6months [2 lakh IU each] till 5yrs of age.
  • Hence DPT booster & Vit A are applicable at the age of 5 yrs.
  • 5 doses of OPV is completed with in 16-24months of age normally ; only in delayed immunization, it can be given till 5yrs of age.
  • Other recent changes in immunization guidelines in India:
  • 2 doses of Measles vaccine:-
    • first dose: 9 months of age.
    • second dose: 16-24 months age.
  • 2 doses of JE Live vaccine:
    • First dose : 9-12 months.
    • Second dose =16-24 months.

questions.text: In a rural village as per Chadha committee recommendations there should be 1 Basic Health worker per _____ population?
questions.solution: The Committee also recommended that the vigilance operations through monthly home visits should be implemented through basic health workers.One basic health worker per 10,000 population was recommended. These workers were envisaged as "multipurpose" workers to look after additional duties of collection of vital statistics and family planning, in addition to malaria vigilance. The Family Planning Health Assistants were to supervise 3 or 4 of these basic health workers. At the district level, the general health services were to take the responsibility for the maintenance phase.

questions.text: A 9 Yr. old boy, while riding a bicycle was hit by a four-wheeler and suffered generalized abrasions over both lower limbs, rushed to a nearby hospital Inj Tetanus toxoid was administered, and wound cleaning and dressing done. All of the following are false regarding the given Pathology except:

choices.text: Chemical mediators such as histamine play a role in delayed vascular leakage
Hallmark of the given pathology is increased permeability in the post-capillary venules
Transcytosis is not a contributing factor to vascular leakage
In most cases, vascular leakage starts several hours after injury

questions.solution:
• Several mechanisms are responsible for theincreased permeability of post capillary venules, which is a hallmark of acute inflammation.
  • Chemical mediators such as histamine, bradykinin, leukotrienes, produce endothelial cell contraction which is theimmediate transient response.
  • This results inincreased inter endothelial spaces - the common mechanism of vascular leakage.
  • In most cases,leakage starts immediately after injuryand is sustained for several hours until the damaged vessels are repaired.
  • Increased transport of fluids and proteins through the endothelial cell, calledtranscytosis, also contributes tothevascular leakage

questions.text: A 25year old male returning from South America to India was kept in quarantine by the airport authorities. Due to recent advances in Health care system, quarantine has been replaced nowadays by which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Quarantine has been replaced with active surveillance.
  • Quarantineis the restriction of activities of apparently healthy persons who have been exposed to a case of communicable disease during its period of communicability, for the duration of it's maximum incubation period.
  • Active surveillanceis the continuous scrutiny of all aspects of a disease and application of information to health promotion and to disease prevention and control.

questions.text: A patient has repeated trauma over the gingival mucosa and presented to the clinician as red pedunculated lesion which bleed on touch and ulcerated, surgical excision was done and histopathological picture is given below. Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
Pyogenic granulomas

  • Capillary haemangiomas that present as rapidly growing red pedunculated lesions on the skin, gingival, or oral mucosa.
  • They bleed easily and are often ulcerated.
  • Histologically, they are composed of thin-walled capillaries with scant stroma.

questions.text: A community has total population 10000. Children ranging 0-6 years are 2000. Literate persons among > 7 years of are 4000. What is Effective literacy rate?
questions.solution:
• Effective literacy rate (ELR) = no. of literates / Total population > 7 years age X 100

In the given question,

  • Total population = 10000, Population 0-6 years age = 2000
  • So population > 7 years age = 10000-2000 = 8000
  • So ELR = 4000/8000 X 100 = 50%

questions.text: A 6-year-old child belonging to Punjabi family with past history of blood transfusions presented with haemoglobin 4.5 g/dl, MCV – 70 fl, RDW - 22. Peripheral smear reveals anisopoikilocytosis with microcytic hypochromic anemia and target cells. There is reduced osmotic fragility. What is the the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Comparing the given history & options one by one:

  • Reduced values of MCV and MCHC: microcytic hy­pochromic anemia (G6PD deficiency is ruled out)
  • 6year old and Punjabi ethnicity, history of repeated blood transfusions- in favour of thalassemia, (rules out IDA, need for repeated transfusions unlikley in IDA)
  • Osmotic fragility is reduced: in favour of thalas­semia again, though it may be seen in sickle cell also.
  • Also, the hemoglobin level in the question is more suggestive ofsevere anemiawithpositive history of multiple blood transfusionsboth being important pointers towardsthalassemia major.
  • Please note that apart from Punjabis, other ethnic groups having high prevalence of thalassemia are Sindhi’s, Gujaratis, Parsis, Bengalis and Lohan’s.

questions.text: Most potent stimulator of naive T cell is:
questions.solution:
Dendritic cells(sometimes calledinterdigitating dendritic cells) are themost important antigen-presenting cellsfor initiating T-cell responses against protein antigens. The following contribute to this:

  • First, these cells are located at the right area to capture the antigens under epithelia, the common site of entry of microbes and foreign antigens, and inthe interstitia of all tissues, where antigens may be produced.
  • Second, dendritic cells express high levels of MHC and other molecules needed for presenting antigens to and activating T cells. Also, dendritic cellsexpress many receptors for capturing and responding to microbes (and other antigens), includingTLRs and lectins.

questions.text: A 77year old male was diagnosed with senile cardiac amyloid, which of the following protein is major component in this deposit?
questions.solution:
In case of senile cardiac amyloid transthyretin is main component of the amyloid deposit. This is a normal serum protein which is produced in liver for transport of thyroxine. Localized cardiac amyloidosis has better prognosis than systemic amyloidosis.

Senile cardiac amyloid can present as restrictive cardiomyopathy, arrythmias, ischemic or vulvar diseases.

questions.text: A 45year old male was diagnosed with acoustic neuroma. Which of the following is a gold stranded investigation for this condition?

questions.text: 65 years old male came to your clinic with complaints of Sensorineural hearing loss associated with vertigo and tinnitus. To rule out labyrinthitis, you are thinking of doing Fitzgerald-hall pike test. Which of the following is stimulated by this test?
questions.solution:
• CALORIC TESTS
    • The principle of the caloric test is that changes in temperature in the external auditory canal influence the level of activity of the vestibular labyrinth.
  • How to perform:
    • In order to obtain a satisfactory nystagmus response, the subject has to lie down with the head raised 30 degrees above horizontal. This places the lateral semicircular canal in an approximately vertical position;the more lateral position of this canal leaves it more accessible to external temperature changes.
  • The caloric test stimulates thelateral semicircular canal, the bulge of which is present on the medial wall of the middle ear.
  • Water irrigation at30°C and 44°C(37 ± 7°C) is the standard technique.
  • Each irrigation should last for 40 sec.
  • RESULTS:
    • Cold irrigation induces horizontal nystagmus beating in the opposite direction of irrigation, and ipsilaterally during warm irrigation(cold-opposite-warm-same (COWS).

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a painless mass anterior to her left ear. The mass had been slowly enlarging over the past year. The mass is firm and nontender. Computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging reveal a well-circumscribed, homogeneous mass within the left parotid gland. Biopsy reveals anastomosing strands of stellate and fusiform epithelial cells embedded in a myxoid stroma. Which of the following is a characteristic of the lesion?

choices.text: It is also called papillary cystadenoma lymphomatous
It is most often localized to the submandibular gland
It is the most common malignant salivary gland tumor
Recurrence often takes place after surgical resection

questions.solution:
Pleomorphic adenoma/ Mixed tumor.

  • Approximately 80% to 90% of salivary gland tumors originate in theparotid gland& of these, approximately 70% are pleomorphic adenomas.
  • The term “mixed tumor” properly applies to thisbenign tumor, which often demonstrates myxoid & cartilage-like elements in addition to stellate or fusiform epithelial cells.
  • Complete surgical resection is difficult because of the tumour’s proximity to the facial nerve
  • thus, recurrence is frequent

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about strangulated hernia are correct
a) It is an irreducible hernia and signs & symptoms of intestinal obstruction are seen.
b) Cough reflex is Absent
c) Synthetic mesh is used in the repair of strangulated hernia.
d) Strangulation is more common in direct hernia.
questions.solution:
Strangulated hernia

  • Characterised by Intestinal obstruction + impaired vascular supply of the bowel ·
  • MCConstricting agent-Neck of sac Clinical features ·
  • Intestinal obstruction signs and Symptoms like colicky pain, bilious vomiting, non-passage of faeces and flatus.
  • History of sudden pain over hernia followed by Generalized pain
  • On examination
    • Tense and extremely tender hernia
    • Discoloration of skin (Reddish/ Bluish tinge) of skin overlying hernia.

→No cough impulse -

→Diagnosis of Strangulation – Based on clinical examination

Treatment

  • Resuscitation
    • IV fluids
    • IV antibiotics
  • Nasogastric aspiration
  • Foley’s Catheterisation
    • Incision given on most prominent part of hernia

↓

Dissection

↓

Reach sac and open the sac fundus

↓

Collected fluids is aspirated

↓

Examine bowl

Bowel viable Gangrenous bowel

↓ ↓

Redue bowel to excise gangrenous Bowel Peritoneal cavity ↓

Secure Ligature and excise the non-viable part of omentum

Use of synthetic mesh is contraindicated in strangulated hernia (because there is increased risk of infection) · If mesh needed → Use bioprosthetic/absorbable mesh

questions.text: A 12 years old boy has a dirty grey membrane on tonsil, tonsillar pillars & uvula (as shown below) along with marked lymphadenopathy. On attempting to remove it there is bleeding from the under surface. What could be the best diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Diphtheria typically follows an incubation period of 2-5 days.
  • Infection is slower in onset with less local discomfort often resembling a typical viral upper respiratory infection (URI)
  • Localized or coalescing pseudo membrane in diphtheria extends beyond the tonsils, on to the soft palate and is dirty grey in colour. It is characterized by the formation of a dense, gray debris layer composed of a mixture of dead cells, fibrin, RBCs, WBCs, and organisms
  • It is adherent, and its removal leaves a bleeding surface.
  • Urine may show albumin.
  • Smear and culture of throat swab will reveal Corynebacterium diphtheriae

questions.text: A 54-year-oldoverweightfemalecomplains of decliningvisible acuity. Funduscopicexam indicates peripheral retinal microaneurysms. Urinalysisexhibits3+ proteinuria and3+ glucosuria. Serum albumin is3g/dL, and serumLDL cholesterol is 350 mg/dL. These clinicopathologic findings aredefined through which ofthe subsequent mechanisms of disease?
questions.solution:
• Given clinical features point towards nephropathy&retinopathyresulted as complication oftype-2 DM
  • Type-2 diabetes mellitusresults from complex interplay b/w
    • Underlying insulin resistance in its metabolic target tissues (liver, skeletal muscle & adipose tissue) &
    • Reduction in glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, which fails to compensate for increased demand for insulin.
  • In obese persons, release of inhibitory mediators from adipose tissue interferes with intracellular signalling by insulin.
  • Hyperinsulinemiasecondary to insulin resistance also downregulates number of insulin receptors on plasma membrane.

Other choices are not related to pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: A 60 year old man presents with sudden onset of abdominal and flank pain. On examination, a pulsatile abdominal mass is identified and investigations reveal 6 cm size abdominal aortic aneurysm. A surgery is planned for his treatment. Which of the following is NOT an indication for a surgery in abdominal aortic aneurysm?

choices.text: Diameter > 5.5 cm in males and > 5 cm in females

questions.solution:
Triad of AAA

  • Sudden onset of mid abdominal or flank pain
  • Shock seen only in 1/3rd of cases
  • Pulsatile abdominal mass

Investigations

  • X-ray – Eggshell pattern of calcification
  • Investigation of choice for screening of abdominal aortic aneurysm – USG
  • Investigation of choice for diagnosis & planning repair of abdominal aortic aneurysm – CT
  • Investigation of choice for diagnosis & planning repair of abdominal aortic aneurysm in patients of renal failure – MRI

Indications of surgery in AAA

  • Diameter ³5.5cm/³5cm in females
  • Symptomatic aneurysm
  • Rate of expansion >1cm/year
  • Atypical aneurysm (pseudoaneurysm, dissecting aneurysm, saccular aneurysm)

questions.text: 28 years old male came to the hospital with the diagnosis of Potts puffy tumor. You and your senior resident planning for the resection of the tumor. In the nasal endoscopy, endoscope is guided through an elevation, anterior to the middle turbinate. Your senior resident questioned you "what is that elevation?"
questions.solution:
AGGER NASI:

  • It is an elevation just anterior to the attachment of middle turbinate.
  • It is also called the naso-turbinal concha and the nasal ridge.
  • In 90% of patients an anterior ethmoidal cell (called the "agger nasi cell") can be found in the lacrimal bone below the agger nasi ridge, which communicate with the frontal recess.
  • An enlarged agger nasi cell may encroach on frontal recess area, constricting it and causing mechanical obstruction to frontal sinus drainage.
