questions.text: A 43-year-old man is complaining of diarrhea, cramping abdominal pain, postprandial nausea and vomiting for the past five days. He also has dizziness, generalized sweating, and shortness of breath. He had a partial gastrectomy for a bleeding gastric ulcer one month ago.Examination reveals a mildly distended abdomen with increased bowel sounds. The epigastrium is mildly tender, and the postsurgical scar is healing well. Which of the following will be the most important step for initial management of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Start a low carbohydrate and a high-protein diet
Admit the patient for correcting the surgery

questions.solution:
The patient in the question has dumping syndrome, a complication of gastrectomy.

DUMPING SYNDROME Constellation of symptoms due to accelerated empying / dumping of hyperosmolar content into proximal part of small intestine.

More common in – Billroth- II> Billroth-I

Early dumping Late dumping
  • Seen with 15-30 min of meals
  • Hyperosmolar content in jejunum

↓

Increase secretion in jejunum

↓

Third – space loss ↓

Hypovolemia
  • Seen after 2-3 hours of meals ·
  • Hyperosmotic / Hyperglycemic content in jejunum ↓

Increased release of insulin ↓

Leading to Reactive Hypoglycemia ↓

Treatment – oral glucose

“PREVENTION IS BETTER THAN CURE”

Prevention of dumping syndrome

  • Dietary modification
    • Small frequent meals
    • Low carbohydrate, high fat, high protein diet
    • Avoid high calorie drink o Avoid liquids during meals
  • If patient is not improving after dietary modification o
    • Octreotide intake (Somatostatin analogue)- To decrease secretion of GIT and to decrease insulin release.
  • If patient not improving even after Octreotide intake o
    • Surgery

1. Convert BILLROTH II to BILLROTH I

2. Interposition of anti-peristaltic segment of Jejunum

questions.text: A 30y/o male presented to dermatology OPD with following findings, on KOH mount examination spaghetti and meatball like appearance was seen. What will the color this condition will show under wood’s lamp?
questions.solution: Spaghetti and meat ball appearance and the given lesions are suggestive of pityriasis versicolor, which show faint yellow color under wood’s lamp

questions.text: Patient with depigmented macules or patches, milky-white in color, well-demarcated over face, neck, dorsum of hands, scalp, and trunk. Patient also has premature greying of hair. which of the following disease is not associated with the given disorder?
questions.solution:
DISORDERS ASSOCIATED WITH VITILIGO

Vitiligo has an autoimmune pathology and is therefore more commonly associated with other autoimmune conditions

  • Thyroid disease:
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Hypothyroidism
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Addison’s disease
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypoparathyroidism
  • Myasthenia gravis
  • Alopecia areata
  • Morphoea and lichen sclerosis

Androgenetic alopecia -patterned hair loss seen more commonly in men due to end organ testosterone hypersensitivity over hair follicles of scalp (fronto-temporal parietal areas).

questions.text: A 76 year old man presents with a brownish pigmented lesion on his back. He noticed that the lesion has been increasing in size over 4-6 weeks. He otherwise feels well. On examination, the lesion is 6.5 cm in size, has asymmetrical borders and variation in color. Biopsy is done and malignant melanoma is reported. What is the best treatment option for this patient?

choices.text: Wide local excision withs sentinel lymph node biopsy

questions.solution:
Malignant melanoma 01:07:42

  • Caused by malignant transformation of Junctional melanocytes·
  • Junctional melanocytes are located at Dermo epidermal junction.·
  • Most common site of malignant melanoma
  • In males: back & trunk
  • In females : lower extremity

Pathology

  • Following markers are positive for malignant melanoma
  • S-100
  • HMB 45
  • Vimentin
  • Following markers are negative for Malignant melanoma
  • CK-20

Risk factors

  • Xerodermapigmentosa
  • UV radiation exposure
  • Family history of Malignant melanoma
  • Dysplatic nevus
  • Giant congenital melanocytic nevus
  • Multiple melanocytic nevi
  • History of sunburn

Characteristic features

  • A- Asymmetry
  • B- Border irregularity
  • C- Colour variation
  • D- Change of diameter >6mm
  • E- Evolution change in size, shape, color or another trait
  • MC route of spread – lymphatic
  • MC site of metastasis – liver

Investigations

  • For small lesions- full thickness excisional biopsy
  • For large lesions- Incisional biopsy

Treatment

  • Wide local excision with Sentinel lymph node biopsy
  • Margins to be taken depends on the tumor thickness and depth of invasion
  • <1mm thickness : 1cm margin
  • 1-4mm thickness : 2 cm margin
  • >4mm thickness : 2-3 cm margin
  • Malignant melanoma is a radio resistant tumor
  • Chemotherapy – IFN-a 2b is useful

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about Marjolin’s Ulcer except-

choices.text: It can arise from low grade squamous cell carcinoma.
Regional lymph node metastasis is commonly seen.
It is managed by surgery followed by flap cover.

questions.solution:
Marjolin’s Ulcer

  • Low grade SCC
  • Arises from long standing scar tissue and chronic benign ulcer

MU develops in

  • Post burn scar
  • Long standing venous ulcer
  • Chronic ulcer due to trauma
  • Chronic discharging osteomyelitis sinus
  • Post radiation ulcer

Characteristic features

  • Painless (no nerves in scar tissues)
  • Slow growing (avascular scar)
  • Radio resistant (avascular scar)
  • No regional LN metastasis (no lymphatics in scar tissue)

IOC → Biopsy

Management

  • Surgery followed by flap cover
  • Ratiotherapy should be avoided (because this malignancy arises from scar tissues that it already avascular)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are True about keloid?
i) Keloid comprises of abundance of immature fibroblasts with immature blood vessels. ii) Keloid is a type of tumor that has a high tendency to recur after local excision.
iii) Keloid could be hereditary.
iv) It is mostly seen over incision sites, vaccination sites, piercing sites.
v) Keloid scars can become smaller with time.
questions.solution:
In hypertrophic scar, there is hypertrophy of mature fibroblasts in hypertrophic scar. Blood vessels are minimal in this condition. However, in keloid, proliferation of immature fibroblasts with immature blood vessels are found. These two conditions represent variations in the normal process of wound healing. Keloid is very common in blacks and least common in Caucasians. Keloid is not a true tumor but has a marked tendency for local recurrence after excision.

Difference between Hypertrophic scar & Keloid

HYPERTROPHIC SCAR KELOID
Genetic
  • Not familial
  • May be familial
Race
  • Not race related
  • More common in Blocks > whites
Sex
  • Females = males
  • Female > males
Age
  • Children
  • 10 to 30 years
Border
  • Remains within the wound
  • Outgrows wound area
Sites
  • Flexor surface
  • Sternum
  • Shoulder
  • Face
Etiology
  • Related to tension
  • Unknown
Development
  • Within 4 weeks
  • 3 months to 1 year
Clinical findings
  • Raised
  • Some pruritis ·
  • Respects wound confines
  • Pain
  • Pruritis
  • Grows beyond the wound margins
Histology
  • Parallel orientation of type III collagen fibers
  • Thick wavy type I & III collagen in random orientation

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an indication for lumbar sympathectomy?
questions.solution:
LUMBAR SYMPATHECTOMY

  • Intermittent claudication is not an indication
  • Usually L1 to L4 ganglia removed
  • In B/L Lumbar sympathectomy, at least L1 on one side should be preserved to prevent retrograde ejaculation
  • Structure mistaken for lumbar sympathetic ganglia and accidently removed are
    • G-Genito Femoral Nerve
    • P- Psoas sheath, Psoas minor
    • L-Lymphatics

Indications for lumbar sympathectomy

  1. Buerger’s disease (Rest Pain)
  2. Atherosclerosis
  3. Raynaud’s disease
  4. Acrocyanosis
  5. Causalgia
  6. Hyperhidrosis
  7. Erythrocyanosis
  8. Frost bite

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is admitted to the hospital after a motor vehicle accident resulted in a left tibia fracture and multiple rib fractures. Initial management was started for the patient. After 12 hours, he experienced a crawling and burning sensation and worsening pain in his left leg. The left leg is swollen and tense. On examination, pulses are palpable in both lower extremities and severe pain is felt by the patient on passive flexion of left leg. Compartment syndrome is suspected in this patient. What is the best investigation for diagnosis of compartment syndrome?

choices.text: Duplex ultrasound of the lower limbs

questions.solution:
• Compartment syndrome
  • Typically occur in closed lower limb injuries

Clinical features

  • Severe pain
  • Pain on passive movement of affected compartment muscle Distal sensory disturbances
  • Absence of distal pulses (late sign)

Investigation

  • For diagnosis – Compartment pressure is measured ↓

Pressure monitor & catheter inserted into muscle compartment

Treatment

  • Fasciotomy
  • Indication for fasciotomy
  • If compartment pressure is >30mmHg
  • Clinical signs and symptoms of compartment syndrome Procedure
  • Two longitudinal incisions should be given – one on Medial and the other on lateral side
  • Incised layer are
    • Skin
    • Subcutaneous fat
    • Fascia
  • After incision, Muscle should be bulging through fascia

questions.text: Which is the most commonly used vascular graft for coronary artery bypass surgery?
questions.solution:
VASCULAR GRAFT 01:35:32

  • It is of 2 types
Bioprosthetic Synthetic
  • Auto graft
  • Homograft (Allograft)
  • Xenograft (Heterograft)
  • Tissue engineered
  • Textile graft – Dacron (most common)
  • Non- Textile graft
    • ePTFE (expanded polytetrafluoroethylene)
    • Polyurethane
  • Best natural vascular graft – Reversed long saphenous Vein
  • Best synthetic vascular graft – Dacron
  • Conduit of choice / Preferred graft for infra-inguinal bypass- Saphenous vein
  • Conduit of choice / Preferred for supra-inguinal bypass – Dacron
  • Most commonly used graft for CABG (Coronary Artery Bypass Graft)- Long saphenous Vein
  • Most preferred graft for CABG – LIMA (left internal mammary artery)

↓

  • Has higher patency rate than long saphenous vein because

→ LSV has collapsible lumen (i.e. lumen is open during systole but collapse during diastole) whereas in LIMA lumen is open during systole and diastole

  • But LSV is more commonly used because of its advantage of extra length
  • Radial artery bypass can also be used for CABG.

questions.text: A 71 year old woman is diagnosed with pleomorphic adenoma and a superficial parotidectomy is planned. Before the procedure, the surgeon discusses possible complications of the surgery. He mentions a complication that could cause sweating and redness around the ear upon smelling or tasting the food. What is the treatment of the above-mentioned complication of parotidectomy?
questions.solution:
Complication of Parotidectomy

  • Facial nerve paresis / paralysis
  • Sensory abnormalities due to sacrifice of greater auricular nerve
  • Frey’s syndrome
  • Parotidfistula

FREY’S SYNDROME 00:37:46

  • Aka Auriculotemporal syndrome / Gustatory sweating
  • Injury of Auriculotemporal nerve – Causes aberrant cross innervation

↓

Parasympathetic secretomoter fibers & Sympathetic fibers supply sweat glands

Clinical features

  • On tasting food or Smell of food – causes Autonomic stimulation Leads to Sweating & erythema at parotid region

Diagnosis

  • Minor’ starch iodine test

Management

  • Anti-perspirant application
  • Botox injection
  • Tympanic neurectomy – for non – responding cases

questions.text: Which is not a correct statement for negative pressure wound therapy for treatment of pressure ulcers?

choices.text: A negative pressure (-125 mmHg) creates a vacuum that draws out excess fluid from the wound and increases the blood supply.
It can be used continuously or intermittently as treatment.
This treatment therapy protects the wound environment from outside micro-organisms and keeps wound moist and warm.
It is used for a necrotic tissue with eschar.

questions.solution:
Vaccum assisted closure

  • Aka negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT)· (-125mmHg) pressure is applied 2-3 times a week
  • Promotes wound healing by applying vacuum through a spaical sealed dressing ·
  • Continued vacuum by NPWTo
    • Draws out fluid from wound
    • Increases blood flow to the area.

  • Aka negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) ·
  • (-125mmHg) pressure is applied 2-3 times a week ·
  • Promotes wound healing by applying vacuum through a spaical sealed dressing ·
  • Continued vacuum by NPWT
    • Draws out fluid from wound
    • Increases blood flow to the area.
  • Vacuum can be applied continuously or intermittently.

Primary effects of NPWT

Causes Macrodeformation → draws wound edges together ↓

Contraction (helps in wound edge approximation)

  • Stabilization of wound environment – by protecting the wound from outside microorganisms, provides warm & moist environment to wound
  • Reduces edema – by removal of soft tissue exudate Microdeformation leading to cellular proliferation on wound surface

Contraindications of NPWT – MUNNA

  • Malignancy in the wound
  • Untretedosteomyelitis
  • Non enteric & undrained fistula
  • Nectotic tisue with eschar

questions.text: Massive bleeding due to severe lacerations involving liver could be temporarily controlled by Pringle’s maneuver, also called total flow occlusion. It involves clamping in foramen of Winslow. This maneuver is used to control bleeding from which of the following source?
questions.solution:
PRINGLE’s Maneuver

  • Aka Total in flow Occlusion
  • Clamping in foramen of Winslow and we occlude the Portal triad.
  • It controls bleeding from portal vein and Hepatic Artery.
  • Bleeding is effectively controlled from Portal Vein as compared to hepatic Artery.
  • It doesn’t control bleeding from IVC and Hepatic Vein
